text:
Hey y’all! This might be a bit random but I’m curious about whether people have interesting thoughts, experiences, insights about being a content writer and having ADHD. Recently I was diagnosed with ADHD (at 30 :sweat_smile: ) which has been really enlightening. A lot of things are falling into place thanks to this new information about how my brain works.

One thing I’m experiencing as I try out medication, is that the way I write is completely different when I’m on ADHD meds. This quote has always been extremely true for me, “I hate writing but I love having written”. But on ADHD meds I’m starting to think maybe I can love the process of writing too. I’m achieving a fun writing flow much more easily :tada:

A different unexpected change is that I’m suddenly able to be much more perfectionistic in my writing. I’ve never been able to focus on one sentence for too long. The tediousness of getting it right was just too much for my ADHD brain. I think this served me to an extent because I was able to move quickly and not hem and haw on each sentence for too long.

So now I’m faced with a new challenge: I am able to focus way better on my writing but I’m not necessarily writing more efficiently. I’m overthinking sentence structure and word choice in a way I never used to.

There’s a lot Im processing around this diagnosis and I’d be really interested to hear other people’s experience with content writing and ADHD. Or on getting an ADHD diagnosis later in life and what’s changed because of it.

text:
Heya <@U01GLCVCT89>, I have been down this road and TG am on the right meds for almost 15 years now.
For me, there are 2 things that help my writing. Get sleep... :slightly_smiling_face: If you are on hectic schedules, then scrap the "8 hours a night" and at least grab one or two 1.5 hour sleep sessions in the day. Switch off you phone. No disturbances. These cat naps will save you damn life. Trust me.

Then on the writing. I find that when my focus starts to wane, it's because my mind is getting bored. And just like you, it's when I am fixating on a particular line or paragraph.
What works for me, is pausing that section , and rather working on the ending, or doing a bit of research on another section that still needs research. If all else fails, I go look for images for my article and then can play with Photoshop for a bit - which I love :slightly_smiling_face: .

I then find that my hind brain has now finished going over the various nuances on that creative blocking sentence that was giving me grief, and after a coffee and a smoke, I smash it out perfectly.

This works for me at least. :wink:

text: Hey Brett! Thanks for these tips! I like how you’ve taught yourself to be distracted by other productive tasks that help the writing along in other ways. Useful stuff that I’ll definitely try out!

elements.text: Hey Brett! Thanks for these tips! I like how you’ve taught yourself to be distracted by other productive tasks that help the writing along in other ways. Useful stuff that I’ll definitely try out!

text: All good and no worries. I have gone through the tunnel and come out pretty happy on the other side. So anything I can do to help other struggling, especially if they are new into their diagnosis, I will do. So please feel free to reach out any time. I am super chilled, unless I am work swamped, then I'll take a bit to respond.

text: One of my favorite authors was recently diagnosed with ADHD as well and I found his article <https://www.raptitude.com/2021/03/what-raptitude-has-always-been-about/> incredibly moving and eye-opening.

attachments.title: What Raptitude Has Always Been About
attachments.text: NOTE: This post is a very personal one, even for this blog. It describes a major revelation I recently experienced (a positive one) and what it means for Raptitude readers. It’s the longest post I’ve written in years. There is also a small chance it will lead to a similar bombshell discovery in your own life. *** In the Truman
attachments.fallback: Raptitude.com: What Raptitude Has Always Been About

elements.text: One of my favorite authors was recently diagnosed with ADHD as well and I found his article

text:
This is fascinating to me because I was diagnosed when I was 16, way back in 1996 and way before I was a writer. So all I've ever known is writing with meds.

I'm always overthinking while I write and had to go through CBT to learn ways to stop it.
